action: Ask if patient has tried over-the-counter pain relief. If severe, persistent, or accompanied by vision changes or confusion, offer same-day GP appointment.
Ask about duration and severity. If mild and under one week, advise salt-water gargle and OTC remedies. If difficulty swallowing, high fever, or lasting over a week, book GP appointment.
If under 3 weeks and mild, advise OTC cough syrup and hydration. If over 3 weeks, associated with shortness of breath, chest pain, or blood, book GP appointment.
Advise paracetamol and hydration. If fever is very high, lasts more than 5 days, or patient is very unwell, book GP appointment.
If mild and less than 3 days, advise OTC pain relief. If severe, persistent, or accompanied by hearing loss or discharge, book GP appointment.
If less than a week, advise steam inhalation and OTC decongestants. If severe facial pain or lasting over 7-10 days, book GP appointment.
If severe, crushing, or with breathlessness, advise calling emergency services immediately. Otherwise, book urgent same-day GP appointment.
Ask duration and severity. If mild and short-term, advise OTC antacids or pain relief. If severe, persistent, or with vomiting, fever, or blood in stool, book GP appointment.
If mild and less than a week, advise OTC pain relief and gentle exercise. If severe, persistent, with numbness or difficulty passing urine, book GP appointment.
If mild and no systemic symptoms, advise over-the-counter creams or pharmacist consultation. If painful, spreading rapidly, or with fever, book GP appointment.
If mild and recent onset, advise increased fluids and consider pharmacist advice. If persistent, severe, with fever or blood in urine, book GP appointment.
If mild, advise pharmacist for eye drops. If vision changes, severe pain, or light sensitivity, book GP appointment.
If mild and short-term, advise lifestyle changes and OTC laxatives. If persistent, severe pain, or bleeding, book GP appointment.
If less than 48 hours, advise hydration and OTC anti-diarrheal. If lasting more than a week, or with blood or severe dehydration, book GP appointment.
If short-term and mild, advise hydration and rest. If persistent, bloody, or patient is unable to keep fluids down, book GP appointment.
If recent strain or mild ache, advise rest, ice, and OTC pain relief. If swelling, redness, or difficulty bearing weight, book GP appointment.
Direct to community pharmacist if about minor side effects or over-the-counter meds. If prescription issues or severe side effects, arrange GP phone call.
Advise using the online request system if available or request repeat prescription form. If urgent or medication running out, note for GP to review.
Check if results are back. If normal and routine, advise patient of normal outcome (if practice policy allows). If abnormal or requires discussion, book GP telephone appointment.
If mild, advise self-help resources or online CBT tools. If patient is in distress, suicidal ideation, or severe symptoms, book urgent GP appointment.
If new, changing in size, color, or shape, book GP appointment for examination.
Advise OTC antihistamines or pharmacist consultation. If severe or not responding to OTC meds, book GP appointment.
If short-term and no other symptoms, advise rest and healthy lifestyle. If persistent over several weeks, book GP appointment for assessment.
If mild and occasional, advise hydration and rest. If persistent, severe, or accompanied by fainting or visual changes, book GP appointment.
If superficial, advise cleaning and OTC dressing from pharmacist. If deep, infected, or not healing, book GP or practice nurse appointment.
